items.title: How to use EvalParallel2?
items.body:
I'm trying to use EvalParallel2 to speed up the training, but didn't get any improvements.
The toy code is as follows,
```python
import numpy as np
import cma

multip = 20
size = 8 * 20
w = np.array([1,2,3,4,5,4,3,2]*multip)

def get_fitness(x):
    return np.sum((x-w)**2)

opts = {'popsize' : 256,
        'ftarget': 1e-6
        }
es = cma.CMAEvolutionStrategy([0] *size , 1, opts)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    import time
    time1 = time.time()
    # es.optimize(get_fitness)

    with cma.fitness_transformations.EvalParallel2(get_fitness, 8) as eval_para:
        while not es.stop():
            X = es.ask()
            es.tell(X, eval_para(X))

    time2 = time.time()
    print(time2 - time1)
```

items.title: Avoid C update with negative weights for (bad) injected solutions
items.body:
Injecting always the same arbitrary bad solution twice or more often leads to a failure, similar to the one observe [here](https://github.com/beniz/libcmaes/issues/204#issuecomment-605218175)

```python
es = cma.CMAEvolutionStrategy(8 * [5], 10, {'ftarget': 1e-9,
                                           #'CMA_active': 0,
                                          })
fit = cma.ff.sphere
while not es.stop():
    X = es.ask()
    F = [fit(x) for x in X]
    es.tell(X, F)
    es.inject(2 * [es.N * [100]])
    es.disp(300)
    es.logger.add()
cma.plot(xsemilog=True);
```

A simple fix is to turn off `'CMA_active'`. A (much) better fix would be to catch the points that don't comply with the sample distribution (as is already done) and ignore them in the update of the covariance matrix if they are bad (needs to be done).

items.title: Countevals is only incremented by the number of evaluations on feasible solutions
items.body:
Hi !

Thanks for all the work on this package!

I believe that there is an issue (or an imprecision in the documentation) concerning the `maxfevals` stop criterion when doing rejection sampling using `ask_and_eval`. Indeed, `countevals` is only incremented in `tell`, which can only see the *popsize* samples that have not been rejected. Hence, `countevals` is equals to the number of iterations times *popsize*, which in my opinion isn't its expected behavior. 

For example, using CMA-ES to fit an ODE model to data, many parameters values will fail to be integrated. While I have a maxfevals stop criterion, different runs of the fitting script lead to varying running times, depending on whether the search has encountered a lot of unfeasible points, while I would expect all runs to be about the same duration on the same hardware.

Let me know if I can help you!

items.title: options to be used in _copy_light
items.body:
Currently, the _initial_ options of the given `ES` are used to make a copy.

Pros:
- a new `ES` starts with iteration counter zero, hence it should start with the options used at iteration counter zero
- we typically change ("reset"?) `sigma`, so we may also change the options
- this is what is currently implemented

Cons:
- a copy and continuation of the given `ES` should have the same current options, as it has the same mean and covariance matrix
- `sigma` is in general not set to the original `sigma0`, as this may well "destroy" too much information
- setting options back to their initial value seems slightly counterintuitive

items.title: Injection checking in ask_geno of CMAEvolutionStrategy
items.body:
Undefined variable is detected when checking injections(I am using cma==2.7.0).
```
  File "/~/cma/evolution_strategy.py", line 1759, in ask
    pop_geno = self.ask_geno(number, xmean, sigma_fac)
  File "/~/cma/evolution_strategy.py", line 2030, in ask_geno
    arinj[1] /= sum(arinj[0]**2)**0.5 / s1  # revert change
NameError: name 's1' is not defined
```

For current master branch, the code block is at line 2047 ~ 2055 of `evolution_strategy.py`.
```
arinj[0] *= self._random_rescaling_factor_to_mahalanobis_size(arinj[0]) / self.sigma
arinj[1] *= (sum(arinj[0]**2) / sum(arinj[1]**2))**0.5
if not Mh.vequals_approximately(arinj[0], -arinj[1]):
    utils.print_warning(
        "mean_shift_samples, but the first two solutions"
        " are not mirrors.",
        "ask_geno", "CMAEvolutionStrategy",
        self.countiter)
    arinj[1] /= sum(arinj[0]**2)**0.5 / s1  # revert change
```
It appears **s1** is not defined.

In cma==2.6.0, **s1** was defined as `s1 = sum(arinj[1]**2)**0.5` before updating arinj[1] with `*=`.

items.title: Using CMAEvolutionStrategy instance copies
items.body: The current `_copy_light` method creates a new object with the current `sigma` which hence also becomes `sigma0`. This runs into practical problems if we want to use a much larger `sigma` to continue with the new instance: just increasing `sigma` will trigger the `tolupsigma` termination.

items.title: 'tolfun' termination criteria not correct
items.body:
Under boundary constraints,
cmaes.fit.fit is ordered by function value + boundary penalty (cf: https://github.com/CMA-ES/pycma/blob/master/cma/evolution_strategy.py#L2533)

On the other hand, 'tolfun' terminates CMA-ES iff the function value differs at most opts['tolfun'], but the formula is just taking the first and last element of cmaes.fit.fit. (cf: https://github.com/CMA-ES/pycma/blob/master/cma/evolution_strategy.py#L3422)
This is not necessarily minimum/maximum of the population because of boundary penalty.

This can lead to wrong termination.
Especially, on the 1st epoch, if the function values are only slightly different, es.fit.fit[-1] - es.fit.fit[0] can be even negative and terminates immediately.

items.title: unbiased paths
items.body:
The unbiased but non-random initialization of the paths with all-zeros leads to a bias on their variance ~~which is corrected for by computing `hsig`. However, there seems to be a simpler way to achieve the same objective~~ There seems to be a simple way to remove this bias by computing the learning rate(s) as a function of the iteration number `t=1,2,...` like

```python
c_t = max(1/t, c)
```

See Footnote 3 on page 7 [here](https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01995373v1).

More generally, `c(t)` could be a monotonous sequence which satisfies `c(1) = 1` and `c(t) >= 1/t` (to have always less weight on older data), for example `c(t) = max(2/(t+1), c)`.

More generally, the sequence `c(t)` should obey `c(t+1) >= c(t) / (1 + c(t))` in order to guarantee that at each time step the new data gets at least as much weight as the older data on average. Then, setting `c(1) = 1` makes the result unbiased. Both hold for both above sequences.

In the overall context though, the initial bias has quite limited effects and is most likely nothing to worry about. That is, we might prefer code simplicity over implementing this correction.

items.title: Error with 'B is not orthogonal' specifically on IBM power8 architecture.
items.body:
Suppose running the following code

```
import cma

es = cma.CMAEvolutionStrategy([3]*100, 0.5, {'popsize': 12})
for i in range(1000):
    x = es.ask()
    c = list(range(12))
    
    es.tell(x, c)
    
    print(f'Iteration {i}: es.result["xfavorite"]')
```
After some iterations, it shows the following error
```
B is not orthogonal

    318             print('B is not orthogonal')
    319             print(self.D)
--> 320             print(sum(self.B[:, 0:self.N - 1] * self.B[:, 1:], 0))
    321         # is O(N^3)
    322         # assert(sum(abs(self.C - np.dot(self.D * self.B,  self.B.T))) < N**2*1e-11)

AttributeError: 'GaussFullSampler' object has no attribute 'N'
```

This refers to the latest version 2.6.0. 

------------------Update--------------------------------

After more tests, it works perfectly with all other machines, but just except for IBM Power8 architecture. Quite interesting, I am thinking if it is possible to have something to do with MKL ? Because MKL only supports Intel chips, I installed magma instead.

items.title: Keeping some survivors between generations
items.body:
Hi, in my personal version of CmaEs I tried to keep samples longer than for a single generation. Typically, the fitness computation will take a significant amount of time so if we can re-use it then that's great.

If I keep all of one generation into the next generation and keep the top X% by fitness, convergence suffers. But if I only let them stay around for a single extra generation, convergence picks up and it's for free.

Running Rosenbrock with 8 dimensions over 1000 runs I get these results

*with* keep survivors
1000: t=18.9ms, evals=4195.2, hits=100.00 %

*without* keep survivors
1000: t=20.9ms, evals=4870.7, hits=100.00 %

Meaning a 13+% of evaluation reduction and both converge 100% of the time.

any thoughts?

Notice how the time is roughly the same, that's because fitness evaluations are almost free for this problem, but typically they won't be.

mattias

items.title: pycma always seeds np.random
items.body:
The current code either seeds `np.random` with a user specified seed, or a new random seed:

https://github.com/CMA-ES/pycma/blob/master/cma/evolution_strategy.py#L1359-L1364

This means that if the user seeds `np.random`, then generates random samples, then calls cma, and then generates more samples, the code still produces arbitrary output.

A workaround is to always pass a seed to cma, but it seems to me that changing the state of `numpy.random` (unless asked specifically) is a side-effect that should be eliminated

items.title: CMADataLogger instance has a dynamic data path
items.body: When using a `CMADataLogger` instance interactively, it reads the data always from the current folder. This is a kind-of unexpected behavior. The filename prefix should probably better be constructed with the full current path at instantiation prepended. The current behavior can always be recovered by just generating a new instance.

items.title: Weird variance change with mirrors in high dimension
items.body: ```python es = cma.fmin2(cma.ff.elli, 360 * [1], 1, {'CMA_diagonal':True, # 'CMA_mirrormethod': 0, 'CMA_mirrors':True, # 'AdaptSigma': cma.sigma_adaptation.CMAAdaptSigmaCSA, 'popsize': 160, 'maxiter': 1200, 'ftarget': 1e-9, })[1] cma.plot() ``` We see a change of a coordinate-wise standard deviation by a factor of up to almost 3000 in a single iteration. This happens only with selective delayed mirrors and diagonal and active update and large population size and large dimension but irrespectively of the step-size adaptation method.

items.title: CMAEvolutionStrategy.mean has invalid shape when some variables are fixed
items.body: `CMAEvolutionStrategy.mean` returns only free (e.g., the optimized) variables, when some variables are fixed using the `fixed_variables` options. The set of candidates returned by `.ask()` is shaped correctly, though.

items.title: Pypi's README indicates `cma.fcts.rosen` instead of `cma.ff.rosen`
items.body: Everything is in the title.

items.title: No linear transformation interval in box constraint handling?
items.body:
https://github.com/CMA-ES/pycma/blob/881ad335a5c446a89752a279e47179472f9e7bb2/cma/transformations.py#L267

In the docstring, it is said that the linear part takes about 90 % of the feasible interval in typical cases, however, au = al = (ub - lb) / 2 result in transforming whole region quadratically. I guess they should be au = al = (ub - lb) / 20.

passing a numpy.ndarray with more than one dimension raises the following error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
```

_PS. this package is amazing, thank you for your hard work!_

items.title: negative impact of injection on performance
items.body: A single injected solution should not have any relevant negative impact on performance, however we can see this: roughly doubling the runtime by introducing a false short axis into C. This suggests that the normalization of the injected point is not correct.

items.title: condition alleviation bug
items.body: Shows up in particular when the condition is high and hence the smallest eigenvalue is increasing by orders of magnitude _and_ eigenvectors are not aligned in the coordinate system. The bug shows up for both, alleviation in coordinates and resetting C=I. ``self.alleviate_conditioning_in_coordinates(1e2)`` was used in this example to see both in on run: ```python import functools import cma f = functools.partial(cma.ff.elli, cond=1e28) frot = cma.fitness_transformations.Rotated(f) es = cma.fmin2(frot, [1] + 3 * [0], 0.1, {'tolconditioncov':False, 'seed': 4, })[1] ```

items.title: parallel function evaluation
items.body: For some real world applications, each function evaluation is expensive to run. So it's necessary to parallelize the fitness evaluation part. I can easily do that in Julia, but my version of CMA-ES is not as feature-full as this package. Do you have any interest in implementing that in Python.

items.title: Calls to builtin eval should be replaced
items.body: by `ast.literal_eval` or by another "less evil" way to go about evaluating a string, possibly using `purecma.safe_str`.

items.title: Inconsistent use of np.random.seed
items.body: Both of `ConstRandnShift` class and `Rotation` class call `np.random.seed`. If seed is not given in the constructors,  the former doesn't call `np.random.seed`, but the latter calls it without an argument, which sets the seed using `/dev/urandom`, therefore we loose the full control of the random numbers. For a bug fixing, I prefer to have full control of random numbers. It is easy to correct, but I am not sure if it is a feature or a bug.

items.title: Non scalar values for sigma0?
items.body:
I am curious as to why only scalar values for sigma0 are allowed. It seems that there shouldnt be any reason why we cannot not have a vector of sigma0 values for each dimension of the optimization problem.

In fact this is possible in the java implementation of CMA-ES: 

https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-math/javadocs/api-3.1/org/apache/commons/math3/optim/nonlinear/scalar/noderiv/CMAESOptimizer.Sigma.html

items.title: doctest of purecma
items.body:
When given as a stand alone file,


```
doctest.testmod(purecma)
```
fails, because the tests contain `import cma.purecma`.

items.body: The VD-CMA-ES test [here in `test.py`](https://github.com/CMA-ES/pycma/blob/master/cma/test.py#L249) *sometimes* fails. The outcome remains stochastic even when `np.random.seed` is set in advance and the rotation of the cigar function is omitted.

items.title: speeding up covariance matrix update
items.body:
Hi

Thanks for making your library available. I noticed that it has been updated to v2 very recently.

When I'm using the cma library as is, I notice that the covariance update is rather slow when the number of parameters exceeds a few thousand, and rather unusable when the number of parameters is > 10000.

After doing some literature search, it seems there are some previous works on speeding this up to reduce the compute complexity from O(N^3) to O(N^2).

http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1144082

I'm wondering if there are any options in the existing library for using such method, or any low-rank approximation options available to speed up the covariance matrix update process so that it can be usable for large number of param size?

I have been trying to use CMA-ES along with other algorithms that are simpler, but scale quickly for a large number of params (for example, simple GA type algorithms, and also one of OpenAI's recent paper on ES).

Best Regards.

items.title: adding a simple_cmaes submodule
items.body: Currently a [`barecmaes2.py`](http://cma.gforge.inria.fr/barecmaes2.py) stand alone code exists, which is comparatively short and easy to read and does not depend on `numpy`. I see no reason though why this should not become a submodule of `pycma`.

items.title: TPA fails with calling `ask` twice
items.body: most likely because `ask` assumes two injected solutions to be present, but they have already been processed in the first call of `ask`. ```python import cma function = cma.ff.rosen dimension = 11 es = cma.CMAEvolutionStrategy(dimension * [0.1], 0.5, {'AdaptSigma': cma.sigma_adaptation.CMAAdaptSigmaTPA }) while not es.stop(): X = es.ask() X = es.ask() F = [function(x) for x in X] es.tell(X, F) es.logger.add() es.disp(1) es.plot() es.result_pretty(); ```

items.title: fixed variables interactions
items.body: The `fixed_variables` option of `CMAEvolutionStrategy` interacts with `minstd` and `maxstd` and `integer_variables` options. This leads to an error for the former and probably to unexpected results for the latter. We may consider to depreciate `fixed_variables` in favour of `fitness_transformations.FixVariables`. In this case the values for above options would need to be explicitly managed by the user.

items.title: Setup.py does not specify utilities subpackage
items.body:
With my python configuration (python 3.5 on Ubuntu 16.04), the `cma.utilities` subpackage does not get installed when I install the cma package from source. My guess is that the `packages` argument of `setup` should include `cma.utilities`.

EDIT: I can confirm that adding `cma.utilities` to the `packages` argument resolves this problem.
